content.description: Climb the face and arete between Eeyore's Smile and Sweet Robert.  Shares same chains and last moves as Eeyore's Smile.  Climb patina edges to a few final slab moves.
content.location: The west face of Heffalump,  On the featured face between the two bolted routes that both climb blocks.

climbs.name: Tiddly Pom
climbs.fa: Brian Cabe and Patty Black Oct 2006

content.description: Start on Pooh's Honey, climb up the short corner crack, then stay right and traverse over and finish on Eeyore Smiles.
content.protection: Some cams/nuts/slings for the traverse then the final upper part of Eeyore Smiles is bolt protected.
content.location: Starts the same place as Pooh's Honey.  Rappel from anchor on Eeyore Smiles.

content.description: Climb an easy slab past several bolts.  On a block just to the right of a large crack, with a large and obvious belay area.  You climb 3 distinct blocks stacked on top of each other on your way to the anchors.
content.location: The west side of Heffalump. To the right of Eeyore's Smile and Two Fer.  See the route photo for Oh Bother for a pic of the route(blocks right of the crack).

climbs.name: Pork Chop
climbs.fa: Patty Black and Brian Cabe Oct 2006

content.description: Climb up initially blocky horizontal shelfs to face.  Up face to anchor.
content.location: Obvious slab on the south side of the Heffalump.  Hike around either right or left and come in from the side to get to the nifty base area.  Rappel route.

climbs.name: Pooh's Honey
climbs.fa: Patty Black and Brian Cabe Oct 2006

content.description: Fun short little face climb.  Climb up the flake crack on the right, then, clip the bolt and climb up the low angle face.  Steeper rock leads to a bolted anchor, or, walk off (straight back and slightly to the left).
content.protection: Bolt protected.  5 bolts.  Optional pro in flake to the right at the start (cam).
content.location: Farthest left route on the west side of the Heffalump.  Rap anchor or walk off.

content.description:
Fun route starting on flake features with trad gear then switching over to a sports climb finish.

Pull up a right slanting shallow flake to a shallow foot shelf and up a right facing corner.

Face climb up past the block (on the left) and finish on face climbing bolts to anchor.
content.protection: Gear for flake/crack down low.  Three or so bolts up high to two bolt anchor.
content.location:
Located just right of Eeyore Smiles.

Rappel route.

content.description:
Make the easy move onto the ledge and clip the first bolt. Move right onto the slab and work upward using the slab and the little water runnel on your left. After sustained slabbing through the 2nd and 3rd bolts you'll finally reach some actual handholds up in the vicinity of the 4th bolt where the challenge eases up.

The 2016 Bingham guide calls this a 5.9 but it seemed harder than that to me. Overall a really fun and challenging little route that was well-protected.
content.location: Just to the right of Pork Chop, roughly the center of the slab.

climbs.name: Oh, Bother
climbs.fa: Brian Cabe and Patty Black Oct 2006

content.description: Grunt up into the crack.  Follow crack up until the shallow ledge.  Then, either straight up the face above, or, traverse left and up.  Top out, walk off.  Or, just climb the newer sports route slightly to the right at the start.
content.protection: Wide crack gear along with a standard crack.  No anchor on the top. but, there's a 5.6 sport route to the right.
content.location: On the right side of the west facing aspect of the Heffalump.  Located to the right of Pooh Corner and Two Fer and follows within a few feet left initially, then about the same line as the later added 5.6 sport route "Sweet Roberta."  Start below a low angle off width crack.  No anchor at the very top of this route, but, the newer sport route "Sweet Roberta" has a set of anchor chains on the upper block.

content.description: Mostly bolted face climb. Crux in lower half. "Best route on the Heffalump?" (Bingham, 2016)
content.location: Farthest right bolted route on SE side of Heffalump.

climbs.name: Heffalump Trap
climbs.fa: Brian Cabe and Patty Black Oct 2006

content.description:
This is an amusing little diversion, and, quite unique.  Climb up to the right of Pooh's Honey (first couple of bolts can be used for pro, slinging long will help with rope drag).  Stem around/over to easily avoid the low angle moss runnel.  Climb up to the small tree, sling it long for pro if desired, then up to the horizontal roof crack.  Get yer guns loaded, start pluggin' cams for gear and jamming whilst moving to the left.  Aim for the hole and wonder if you can a) get into it and b) get through it.

Pooh says, "Then would you read a Sustaining Book, such as would help and comfort a Wedged Bear in Great Tightness?"

"For some minutes he lay there miserably, but when the five hundred and eight-seventh Heffalump was licking its jaws, and saying to itself "Very good honey this, I don't know when I've tasted better," Pooh could bear it no longer."

Fun stuff.

Pooh likes his honey.
content.protection: Clip the first couple of bolts on Pooh's Honey (long slings for the traverse to the right).  Protection:  selection of cams from 1 through 4 camlot (or similar).  A #5 camalot would probably not go unused.
content.location: Immediately to the right of Pooh's Honey.  Either walk off the back side, or, climb around and down (take care!) to the anchor on Pooh's Honey.

content.description: This route lies just right of the bolted Pooh's Honey and the tunnel trad route Heffalump Trap.  Climb directly over the blocks, mantling and clipping bolts as you go. Easy patina with one bolt of cruxy slab moves at the top.  Shares the same chains as all the other west side routes.

A bit of a wandering proposition...

Start up on the right side of the Pork Chop face.  Up over blocky terrain to nicely featured face.  Trend left to end up on a nice crack to summit.
content.protection: Small rack (cams most useful, some small).
content.location: Starts on Katie's Cactus Catastrophe then traverses to the left above the grassy crack to the straight up crack to the right and below Pork Chop.  Finish over to the Pork Chop anchor.
